definitions: Recommended percentage ranges of total calories that should come from carbohydrate, fat, and protein.
Guidelines defining healthy macronutrient intake ranges as a percentage of total energy intake.
Ranges used to plan diets that reduce chronic disease risk while meeting nutrient needs.
Macronutrient percentage targets used for population-level diet planning.
A dietary framework specifying acceptable intake proportions of carbs, fat, and protein.
Percent-based macronutrient recommendations rather than gram-based targets.
Dietary reference ranges used to balance energy intake across macronutrients.
Nutrition guidelines defining safe and effective macronutrient calorie distributions.
A recommended intake level used when an RDA cannot be determined.
An intake estimate based on observed or experimentally determined approximations.
A nutrient guideline used in the absence of sufficient evidence for an RDA.
A reference intake assumed to ensure nutritional adequacy.
A recommended level derived from population intake data rather than requirement data.
A fallback intake standard when scientific evidence is incomplete.
A nutrient intake value intended to cover needs of most healthy individuals.
A dietary benchmark used when EAR/RDA calculations are not possible.
The building blocks of proteins.
Organic compounds that combine to form proteins in the body.
Nitrogen-containing molecules required for tissue growth and repair.
Compounds linked by peptide bonds to form polypeptides and proteins.
Essential and nonessential units required for protein synthesis.
Substrates for muscle protein synthesis and enzyme production.
Molecules that serve structural, metabolic, and signaling roles.
Protein subunits obtained from dietary protein digestion.
A condition in which oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood is reduced.
A state often caused by low hemoglobin or iron deficiency.
A disorder characterized by decreased red blood cell function.
A condition that impairs oxygen delivery to working tissues.
A common nutrition-related disorder affecting endurance performance.
A reduction in blood oxygen transport capacity.
A hematological condition frequently linked to iron deficiency.
A disorder resulting in fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance.
The proportion of a nutrient that is absorbed and available for use.
The fraction of ingested nutrient that enters circulation and tissues.
A measure of how efficiently a nutrient is utilized by the body.
The extent to which a nutrient can be absorbed and metabolized.
A factor influenced by digestion, absorption, and food matrix.
The usable portion of a consumed nutrient.
The effectiveness of nutrient absorption from a food source.
A determinant of how much ingested nutrient becomes biologically active.
A macronutrient that provides energy and supports glycogen storage.
Sugars, starches, and fiber that supply glucose to the body.
The primary fuel source for moderate- to high-intensity exercise.
A macronutrient composed of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen.
Dietary compounds that raise blood glucose and replenish glycogen.
An energy-yielding nutrient critical for athletic performance.
A fuel source stored as glycogen in muscle and liver.
Macronutrients broken down into monosaccharides for energy.
A lipid used for cell membrane structure and hormone synthesis.
A sterol transported in blood via lipoproteins.
A precursor molecule for steroid hormones and bile acids.
A structural component of cell membranes.
A lipid synthesized by the liver and obtained from the diet.
A compound essential for hormone and vitamin D production.
A fat-like substance carried by LDL and HDL.
A molecule necessary for normal physiological function despite health stigma.
Excessive body water loss that impairs physiological function.
A state of fluid deficit that reduces performance capacity.
Loss of body water beyond normal homeostatic range.
A condition resulting from insufficient fluid intake or excess loss.
A hydration deficit affecting thermoregulation and cardiovascular strain.
Body water loss that negatively affects health and performance.
A state associated with increased heart rate and reduced endurance.
Insufficient total body water to maintain optimal function.
A set of reference values for planning and assessing nutrient intakes.
Nutrition standards including RDA, AI, UL, and EAR.
A comprehensive framework for evaluating dietary adequacy.
Population-based nutrient intake recommendations.
Guidelines used to assess and plan diets for healthy individuals.
Reference intake values developed by nutrition authorities.
A system of nutrient benchmarks for health maintenance.
Dietary standards used in nutrition policy and practice.
Non-digestible carbohydrate that supports digestive health.
Carbohydrate that resists digestion in the small intestine.
A nutrient that aids bowel function and glycemic control.
Plant-based carbohydrate that contributes to satiety.
A dietary component associated with cholesterol regulation.
Non-absorbed carbohydrate beneficial for gut health.
A carbohydrate that supports microbiome function.
A non-digestible carb linked to reduced chronic disease risk.
The storage form of glucose in muscle and liver.
A polysaccharide used as a readily available energy reserve.
Stored carbohydrate that fuels moderate-to-high intensity exercise.
Glucose chains stored for rapid ATP production.
The primary carbohydrate reserve in humans.
A key determinant of endurance and performance capacity.
Stored glucose that can be rapidly mobilized.
A critical fuel source depleted during prolonged exercise.
A ranking of how quickly foods raise blood glucose.
A comparison of carbohydrate foods based on glucose response.
A scale describing blood sugar response to carbohydrates.
A measure of carbohydrate quality, not quantity.
An index comparing post-meal glucose rise to a reference food.
A classification system for carbohydrate digestion speed.
A tool for understanding blood glucose impact of foods.
A ranking of carbohydrate foods by glycemic response.
A macronutrient made of amino acids.
A nutrient essential for tissue repair and enzyme production.
A dietary component critical for muscle protein synthesis.
Nitrogen-containing compounds forming body structures.
A macronutrient supporting immune and hormonal function.
A structural and functional nutrient in the body.
Dietary amino acid source required for growth and repair.
A macronutrient composed of polypeptide chains.
Daily intake level meeting needs of nearly all healthy individuals.
A nutrient intake standard covering 97â€“98% of the population.
The most commonly used DRI value for adequacy.
A population-based intake recommendation for health.
A nutrient benchmark designed to prevent deficiency.
An intake level derived from EAR plus safety margin.
The daily amount sufficient for most healthy people.
A recommended intake value for individual planning.
The main form of fat stored in the body.
A lipid composed of glycerol and three fatty acids.
The primary storage form of dietary and body fat.
A major energy reserve in adipose tissue.
Fats transported in blood via lipoproteins.
The predominant lipid found in food fats.
Energy-dense molecules used for long-term storage.
Lipids serving as fuel and insulation.
Organic micronutrients required in small amounts.
Compounds essential for metabolic regulation.
Nutrients that do not provide energy but enable energy metabolism.
Organic substances needed for normal physiological function.
Dietary compounds supporting enzyme and hormone activity.
Micronutrients essential for health and disease prevention.
Organic nutrients required in trace amounts.
Non-caloric nutrients vital for metabolic processes.
